Q&A: Kentucky's John Calipari previews Texas

Q&A: Kentucky's John Calipari previews Texas

Kyle Tucker, ktucker@courier-journal.com 4:08 p.m. EST December 4, 2014

Kentucky basketball coach John Calipari previews Friday's game at Texas

UK coach John Calipari is ready to roll out his two-platoon system.(Photo: Getty Images)

CONNECT 3 TWEETLINKEDINCOMMENTEMAILMORE

Kentucky coach John Calipari today returned the outpouring of love he got yesterday from Texas coach Rick Barnes in advance of the top-ranked Wildcats hosting the sixth-ranked Longhorns tomorrow night at Rupp Arena. Calipari called Barnes a "true friend" and discussed the matchup, some recent tinkering with his platoons and growth from point guard Andrew Harrison (a Texas native). All of it here:

JOHN CALIPARI

On Rick Barnes' praise of him and their relationship: "In this profession we're in, you have acquaintances and then you have friends and then you have true friends. He's a true friend that I've known for so long. See, the first time I met him, he was working at the Pitt basketball camp. He was from Lenoir-Ryhne. He had long hair and he had a toss-back in the backseat of his VW, and he would go camp-to-camp, and that was his station. He'd teach, wherever camp he was at, he did it. You're talking about a guy that worked through the ranks from being an assistant with some great coaches to being at George Mason – they forget he was there for a while – going to Providence, going to Clemson and then getting the opportunity at Texas. He's never changed who he is. He's always been somebody that I could call and we bounce ideas.

COURIER-JOURNAL

Texas basketball coach Rick Barnes butters up Kentucky's John Calipari before showdown

"One of the best things I did when I was coaching UMass, I called him one day and I said -- I call him Ricky B. – I said, 'Ricky B., our defense is so bad.' And it was my first year. We gave up 100 points, like, seven times. Led the nation in giving up 100. I said, 'Tell me what you think I should do.' He goes, 'Well, tell me what you're emphasizing.' And so I had to act like I was real smart – I was, like, 28, 29 years old – and I gave him, like, 20 things. I just kept talking. He let me talk. He said, 'Well if that's what you're emphasizing, that many things. That's why you stink defensively.' He said, 'You need to emphasize four things.' And from that point on, I've only emphasized four things on defense. And we've become a pretty good defensive team.

"But he's somebody that, like I said, he's one of those good guys. We'd be friends if we weren't in coaching, if I knew him and all those things. Terrific basketball coach. Battler. You watch how hard his teams play, they always do. Doesn't get caught up in the minutiae of this stuff, the back-and-forth, the he-say, she-say. He doesn't deal with it. He just coaches basketball. He's a Basketball Benny. Loves the game. If I feel like talking basketball, I call him, and I know we can spend a half-hour talking ball."

On Barnes saying he was buttering up Calipari to ask for a big favor and if he's asked it yet: "Nah. He may. He's one of those guys that – like, a lot of us in this profession, we're afraid to talk nice about another coach because it may help his recruiting. You have some guys that think, you know, 'There's only so much oxygen. I got to get mine.' He gets it. And I appreciate what he did. He didn't need to. And let me say it to everybody: It's not as good as it seems, but I'm not as bad as they tell you either. Probably in the middle somewhere, what I am."

On Barnes saying Calipari couldn't guard him as a player: "Probably, but he couldn't play either. There were two of us. I couldn't guard him and he still couldn't make a basket."

On if he'd ever play a home-and-home with Texas: "I think we did a home-and-home. I would do a home-and-home with Texas. We don't have room right now, but I would do it, because of him. But we did go home-and-home with him when I was at Memphis, and they beat us both games."

COURIER-JOURNAL

No Sports Illustrated cover jinx for Anthony Davis

On the challenge of facing a team with the size to stand up to UK in the post: "And they run. They fly up and down the court. They've got good scorers. They've got great length. And they run good stuff. It's gonna be a hard game for us."

On how players are making the platoon system work: "They're doing good. They're doing good. I mean, what you're finding out is this doesn't hurt any players. It's helping players. Now that may not be the case any other time, but what you have are two really good point guards, you've got size on both teams and they're starting to figure each other out. Offensively we're at about 50 to 60 percent capacity right now. We're just not there. Defensively, I would guess we're 70 to 80 percent there, but we're still not where we could be in either area. But offensively we're behind where we are defensively."

On if he's still comfortable with the base platoon groupings: "I messed around this week and I didn't like what I tried, so we're going to going to stick with where we are. But I did mess around, and mainly to see if it helps individuals being on a different group. And it, just like, I'm not – I'm good where we are."

On if some of that tinkering was to motivate players: "No. No. No, they're motivated. It's mainly that – my one thing is how do I keep these guys engaged? What do I do to keep them engaged to where we're trying to move forward, where we keep thinking of ways to get them to think? This is a really smart basketball team. This is a really basketball team. This is a really competitive basketball team. So why not use all those things to keep us stepping forward? And again, nothing would be better for us than having a team like Texas come in and hit us right in the mouth. We need to know when a team comes in and scores their first eight times 10 times down the floor, making tough shots and we're missing open shots, how do we respond? Are we still tough? Are we still having fun? Are we still playing together? Those things are out in front of us yet."

On idea big guys could benefit from playing a team with similar size: "Well, I think we'd rather play against smaller guys, but that may be the case. I'm just looking for our guys – there's not a player on this team I'm asking to do something they can't do. Now, it may be hard and they may want to do something else, but what we're asking each of these guys to do they can do."

On what he want for the other 40 percent of offensive progress: "Well, playing –harder cuts, better screens, better execution, flying down the court so we can get some easy baskets. And I ask you, if we're stopping people 30 percent of the time that means 70 percent of the time we're on a rebound, a break or a steal going the other way or a block going the other day. So we should be scoring at least 25 percent of those. And we're not. So, that's one thing, that's one area. The other area is simply how are we playing? Are we playing the right way? I'm taking every clip of different offenses that we're running to see if it's affective for this team. I told you, we're going to learn. I'm learning. One group may be better playing this way. Another group may be better playing this way. So we'll do whatever the teams need us to do."

On challenges Myles Turner presents: "Terrific player: long, skilled, good around the basket, good open shooter, will make free throws, can really pass. He's a good player, really good player."

On how he gets players to match early intensity of opponents: "That's the players' responsibility, so hopefully they get that every game we play people are jacked up to be playing and be playing here."

On if there is a player he expects to have a breakout game soon: "Well what will happen is, they're feeding off one another. The numbers are so close from minutes to shots to field-goal percentage defense, to rebounds, to points. They're so close, and that one game the white team was really not that good. And then one (game) the blue team wasn't that good. They're kind of feeding off each other, and we haven't had that breakout offensive game yet. I'm trying to explain to them if you play better offense it makes your defense even better, because it puts more pressure on the other team to make baskets against a really good defense. So if you can go down and really execute 10 straight times down the floor, and they're trying to hold the ball and get a shot late in the shot clock, you just put a lot of pressure on that team. But you've gotta have a good offense, too. If you want to be a world-class team, you're not gonna do it just on one end. Both your offense has to be good and your defense has to be good."

On if he's glad, at this time of year, that its' not the defense he's having to harp on: "Um, I am harping on defense, to be honest with you. But no, we're – we give problems because of the mismatches. That's the issue we've had right now."

On what he's told Andrew Harrison about his offense: "Well, Andrew's got a tough job because he's on a unit – there are times he's gotta score, but if that's how he plays then he's hurting himself and hurting our team. But he has to score, too, and there are times in the game that he's just gotta go get a bucket because we're dying. Guy's got his head down, another guy's thinking wrong, and all the sudden – a guy's fading in the post – well, then go get a couple buckets. Because Andrew can score. Andrew could get 20 a game. I mean, scoring, shooting, free throws, layups. He could hit 20 a game. But if he's our leading scorer, we're not winning. But there are games that he must be our leading scorer, and he's got to feel it. It can't be me telling him.

"I even told Willie: 'Tell him, Willie.' If there comes a point where you know, Willie, we're out here dying, (say), 'Andrew, go get some shots; get us a couple baskets.' So he's got a tough job, but he is so much better than a year ago, and so is his brother. His brother's not shooting it good, but it doesn't matter. I'm not worried about. He needs to probably spend a little more time in the gym, but he's – my issue is not … for each individual, what can I give them to make them a little bit better? What are we doing offensively that we can do better or different to make us more effective?"

On Andrew having half as many steals already as all last season and the difference: "It's, again, coaching. Coaching. I'm telling him how to do it. (Laughter) No, please, don't – what I'm basically saying is you can't blame him if I haven't coached him. If I don't teach somebody how to do something and they're not doing it, you can't blame them. But I will say this: In my defense, until he played with great energy and fight, you couldn't worry about the next level. Now he's playing with unbelievable energy. He's playing pick-and-roll defense well. Now the next level for him: Is he a playmaker? Does he have steals, deflections, blocks? Well last year he didn't have many. Now all the sudden we're talking about it, we're emphasizing it, we're showing him in practice where he has opportunities. And he's a really bright kid. He's doing it. So I don't blame him last year. I mean, we literally never got to the point to show him and teach him about being a defensive playmaker. We didn't."

On what he's seen from Marcus Lee lately: "Well, the good news is I looked out my window and he was in the gym an hour early today. I mean, that's part of what he's gotta do. And he's gotta add that 13- to 14-foot game to where we can throw it to him. You can't have a bunch of guys out there they're not guarding. You can't really play offense if that's the case. And then he's got to be an energy guy. When he walks in, there's gotta be a buzz in the building about his energy and his athleticism and his length and, 'Look at this guy.' He can't ever be, like, down. His skill will be that as much as anything else.

"But like I said, I'm happy with all these guys and we – yesterday, the practice was OK; it was good. Wasn't one of our best but it was good. But we haven't had a bad practice. Like, the practices are from good to 'Oh, my gosh.' That's where they're falling right now, and there have been some 'Oh, my goodness, let's just stop; let's get out.' I don't expect them to be playing like it's January right now, especially offensively. We haven't figured it out yet, but I just want to see great energy."

* For instant updates on the Wildcats, follow me on Twitter @KyleTucker_CJ. Email me at ktucker@courier-journal.com.
